comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here we need to keep in mind that this was 1928 and not 1938. I'd say that in 1928 their inspiration might have been Mussolini rather than Hitler. At the time Hitler was still an obscure fringe political figure, and in Italy, provided you weren't a leftist, ordinary people still probably had little idea of the true nature of Mussolini's regime. So I wouldn't rush to read too much into an ?Italian opera troupe giving the fascist salute in 1928. If it was 1938, then different story. But in addition, for all we know the salute might have been at the instigation of the photographer, something done on the spur of the moment, 'for a laugh', etc.

comment._content: Quasimody, the dress is 1928, definitely not 1938 and it was the only year the Gonsalez Opera Company came to Australia. As you say, presumably the salute came without all the later pejoratives in 1928 and fewer people knew of the horrors to come.

comment._content: This is interesting...at the wedding reception for visiting Italian opera stars Toti dal Monte and Enzo de Muro Lomanto, held in Sydney in August 1928, some of the Italian members of the wedding party also gave the fascist salute, whilst singing the fascist anthem 'Giovenezza' - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16488804

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Yes, quasimody, that was a different opera tour of far greater prestige. Melba and Williamson's presented top rate stars in Australia. The Fuller-Gonsalez opera tour was a much lesser affair. Toti dal Monte was to be the world's leading coloratura soprano after Melba's retirement in 1924. She was famous in Europe and then was brought to Australia before she had appeared in the United States.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 66679836@N02
comment._content: Photographs of American children in the 50's, 60's and 70's saying the pledge of allegiance also carry the same stigma... nobody knew the horrors to come of the massive slaughter by the United States in Korea, Vietnam, South America, Iran and Afghanistan, particularly the kids who had no clue what they were doing or what regime they were supposedly pledging allegiance to.  Later when we grew up, we look back and cringe at these photos.
